Executive Summary



Introduction to Risk Management Program



A Risk Management Program (RMP) has been developed for the UNFI facility.  The Risk Management Plan for the UNFI facility has been prepared for the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia in the facility's refrigeration system.  Each part of the RMP is submitted to the Environmental Protection Agency, meeting or exceeding the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.  



The submission is due to the need to fulfill the requirements mandated by the EPA for a new submission or an update to occur every 5 years. The RMP was resubmitted in accordance with the 5-year update requirement.  The RMP resubmission was completed on March 3, 2020.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response or Emergency Action Policies



The UNFI facility recognizes management's responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The controls of accidents have been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the UNFI facility.



To accomplish the company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established an Emergency Action Plan.  The objectives of the Emergency Action Plan are to: maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering and the economic burden resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.



One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response or action programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and EPA's Risk Management Program regulation.  Jeff Compton, the Director of Operations for Colliers International, is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.



The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency re

sponse or emergency action programs is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses, environmental impact and avoid physical property damage.



The accidental release prevention and emergency response or emergency action programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures and practices which govern individual processes, activities or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and are improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled 



The UNFI facility includes an ammonia refrigeration system to provide process cooling capabilities.  The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7664-41-7) contained in each of the systems is in excess of 10,000 pounds.  The maximum quantity of ammonia held during the calendar year is 33,000 lbs. of ammonia. Since an ammonia release from the system could pose a risk of offsite public and/or environmental impact and the system regulated, the systems are subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RM program.



The Prevention Program: 



The Accidental Release Prevention Program focuses on efforts at the UNFI facility to contain the refrigerant inside the systems.  The goal is to reduce the risk of injury and promote safer practices at the UNFI facility. The following items are included in the Prevention Program in relation to requirements for Program Level 3.



1.    Employee Participation (EP)

2.    Process Safety Information (PSI)

3.    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

4.    Operating Procedures (OP)

5.    Training (TR)

6.    Contractors (C)

7.    Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

8.    Mechanical Integrity (MI)

9.    Hot Work Permit (HW)

10.    Management of Change (MOC)

11.    Incident Investigation (II)

12.    Emergency

Planning and Response Program (EP&R)

13.    Compliance Audits (CA)

14.    Trade Secrets (TS)

 

Each of these elements play a role in identifying, evaluating, controlling, and preventing potential hazards associated with the ammonia system. Each element is reviewed and updated with frequencies in accordance with regulations on the EPA and OSHA standards.



Five-Year Accident History



No reportable accidents have occurred at the UNFI facility in the last 5 years. A sample accident report can be found in the Process Safety Management Files. 

 

Emergency Response Program



The UNFI facility contracts service technicians who are trained to respond to small releases that do not necessitate an emergency evacuation. UNFI will not respond to large releases which will require plant-wide evacuation and contacting local Fire and HAZMAT teams. The facility has developed an Emergency Response Plan to define, train on, and plan for each type of release. They are also included in the community's emergency response plan.



The Emergency Action Plan is kept with the Process Safety Management Files.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Based upon ColonialWebb Contractor recommendations, the facility has begun the following plans to improve safety. These items will be assigned responsible parties, tracked and implemented, or closed out with proper justification, to ensure the facility's ammonia refrigeration systems continue to operate safely.



1.    Incorporate evacuation drills to include tenants on the property.

2.    Review potential updates to current ammonia safety systems.

3.    Conduct monthly PSM meetings.

4.    Complete findings and recommendations generated from the most recent Process Hazard Analysis, Mechanical Integrity Audit, and Compliance Audit.
